item.title: Hacker News Top Stories: Monday, April 28, 2025 at 9:15 PM UTC
item.description:
1. Widespread power outage in Spain and Portugal (988 points | 782 comments)
2. Show HN: I built a hardware processor that runs Python (737 points | 211 comments)
3. Show HN: A pure WebGL image editor with filters, crop and perspective correction (114 points | 30 comments)
4. Qwen3: Think Deeper, Act Faster (10 points | 2 comments)

6. Vision Transformers Need Registers (58 points | 8 comments)
7. Migrating away from Rust (241 points | 181 comments)
8. Show HN: Web-eval-agent – Let the coding agent debug itself (49 points | 9 comments)
9. Co-designing a sparse music codec with ChatGPT o3 (6 points | 1 comment)
10. Show HN: Heart Rate Zones Plus – The first iOS app I ever developed (33 points | 15 comments)
11. Tiny-LLM – a course of serving LLM on Apple Silicon for systems engineers (177 points | 19 comments)
12. Why Momentum Works (2017) (25 points | 3 comments)
13. Reports of the death of California High-Speed Rail have been greatly exaggerated (80 points | 137 comments)
14. Activeloop (YC S18) is hiring a VP of Engineering in Mountain View (on-site) ( | hide)
15. My takeaways from DjangoCon EU 2025 (10 points | discuss)
16. It's Not the Incentives (2018) (39 points | 36 comments)

20. Show HN: Autarkie – Instant grammar fuzzing using Rust macros (28 points | 4 comments)
21. Ask HN: What are you working on? (April 2025) (263 points | 763 comments)
22. Is outbound going to die? (40 points | 45 comments)
23. Beating the Crowd (3 points | discuss)
24. DRM-Free OnlyFans Downloads See Widevine Project Nuked from GitHub (15 points | 2 comments)
25. Comparing Voltage Boosting Circuits (4 points | 3 comments)
26. Uncovering the mechanics of The Games: Winter Challenge (237 points | 97 comments)
27. Generating Mazes with Inductive Graphs (2017) (13 points | 3 comments)
28. Presentation Slides with Markdown (220 points | 79 comments)
29. OpenAI Adds Shopping to ChatGPT in a Challenge to Google (11 points | 3 comments)
30. Reversing the fossilization of computer science conferences (68 points | 50 comments)
